issue.title: Relicensing to MIT?
issue.body:
**We are considering changing the license of JSCL from GPL3 to MIT.**

To do so, we need contributors of significant parts of JSCL to agree.

If you are in this list, **please comment in this thread telling us if you agree or not**.

I apology for the ping if you are not interested.

[git-quick-stats](https://github.com/arzzen/git-quick-stats).

comment.body:
> Has there been a final resolution on this yet? If not when could a decision be expected? (sorry for the push)

So, there are some contributors who oppose to it with significant contributions so, this is essentially blocked now.

forkee.name: cornerstone3D-beta
forkee.description: Cornerstone is a set of JavaScript libraries that can be used to build web-based medical imaging applications. It provides a framework to build radiology applications such as the OHIF Viewer.

comment.body:
@kengruven You are right in that many times there is no a good (logical) reason for such a change. In many cases, they could do exactly the same with GPL. I don't think that is true for JSCL.  But regardless,  I think that is the wrong approach, because nobody is going to convince anyone else about it.

That is why, instead, I emphasized the argument of "some people are more comfortable with it", it seems silly, but that is sometimes perfectly valid! Sometimes we accept changes that are not ideal for us, just to keep people on board.  We do that with pull requests all the time.

The fact is, some people want that change, whatever theirs (possibly wrong) reasons. So is this change unacceptable and worth blocking, or not really such a big deal?

(I realize the question doesn't sound 100% honest. We could ask the reverse, "why is changing GPL->MIT a big deal? why can't they concede?" Well, they won't concede and I don't think it's a battle worth picking)

issue.title: Relicensing to MIT?
issue.body:
**We are considering changing the license of JSCL from GPL3 to MIT.**

To do so, we need contributors of significant parts of JSCL to agree.

If you are in this list, **please comment in this thread telling us if you agree or not**.

I apology for the ping if you are not interested.

Some contributions are small enough that we won't need permission. Below follows the contributions by author according to
[git-quick-stats](https://github.com/arzzen/git-quick-stats).

Even if you aren't a contributor, you can react with +1 or -1 to this issue to express your thoughts on the change.

https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/commits/master?author=kengruven

review.body:
Nice!  That is a nice improvement.

I think I'd like a small change.

I would like to keep a function that is useful to make requests programatically. Before this change, that function was `graphql--query` and `graphql-post-request`. But now the callback in them means you can't build your own functions on top of it.

I'd propose to add two arguments `sync` and `success` callback arguments to them, and only pass the callback from the interactive `graphql-send-query` function.

Then it is probably a good idea to still keep the `:parser 'json-read`.  But feel free to add still another argument to it and pass `buffer-string` from the query if you want.

Hm,  with those changes, I also feel comfortable of making the interactive function always async and not even introduce a custom.

Thoughts?

pull_request.title: Implement support for async requests
pull_request.body:
I did this mostly because `request.el` is bugged for me on synchronous requests. But I think it's a nice addition anyway (it has bothered me many times before that emacs would hang while the request is running, specially when I setup some debugging breakpoints in the server).

Hope you find this useful.

Thanks a lot for this package.

comment.body:
> I'm totally OK with the change to MIT, but I'd love to know if there was a motivating factor, and whether the developers think it will encourage their own further development. 🙂

Good point. We're hearing lot of people 'not opposing' to it, but not if it'll make it easier for them to use. I'd love to hear that from others too!

This is the (latest) thread where the topic came up:
https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/discussions/441#discussioncomment-3580135

**My opinion**: I like copyleft but I think it doesn't fit a Lisp implementation well.  I'd like people to feel comfortable that they can use it without making their work GPL too.  By nature in Lisp, it's hard to state what is a 'improvement' to jscl vs just using it.  (what if you do `(defun cl:mapcar ...)` in your application?  I think the simplicity of MIT wins and it would solve that.

comment.body:
Just want to leave my (lack of) opinion here as well.  I don't mind GPLv3 vs MIT, I agree with @nagy's argument, but I think it's unlikely to happen. And even if I don't think there is a reason to reject it because it's GPLv3 (you can make your app on it,  just contribute changes to jscl itself), it seems many people feel that way.

However I have been asked a few timesthis already, so it that makes more people likely to use and contribute to the project, I welcome the change.

issue.title: Relicensing to MIT?
issue.body:
**We are considering changing the license of JSCL from GPL3 to MIT.**

To do so, we need contributors of significant parts of JSCL to agree.

If you are in this list, **please comment in this thread telling us if you agree or not**.

Some contributions are small enough that we won't need permission.
Below follows the contributions by author according to
[git-quick-stats](https://github.com/arzzen/git-quick-stats).

pull_request.title: Some update array features
pull_request.body:
1. (make-array) - now can use :fill-pointer as `t` | `(integer 0 32767)`
2. add function ```(vector-pop vector)```
3. add function ```(vector-push new-val vector)``` 

for details, look at:
1. http://clhs.lisp.se/Body/f_vec_ps.htm
2. http://clhs.lisp.se/Body/f_mk_ar.htm
3. http://clhs.lisp.se/Body/f_vec_po.htm

test cases, also attached

repo.name: jscl
repo.description: A Lisp-to-Javascript compiler bootstrapped from Common Lisp

commits.message:
update MAKE-ARRAY

1. :fill-pointer may be T
2.  check fill-pointer range and type

fix PRINT

fn now return incom object

fix LOAD

delete %js-vref
ugly old function is off
sensitive unofficial comment removed

fix MAKE-ARRAY

lambda form (fill-pointer nil fill-p)
malformed at boot mode
only in REPL

Merge pull request #451 from vlad-km/last-09-22

Some update array features

add stream predicate's

stream-p
start-line-p
output-stream-p

Revert "Add struct STREAM field ' at-line-start'"

This reverts commit 7d91b62a45eaac058996e7fc80dc12ad04ce1480.

add WRITE-SYMBOL

1. new var *PRINT-GENSYM*
2. new symbol predicate
3. modify WRITE-AUX in case
(typecase (form)
  (symbol ....)

fix fn WRITE and  dependent functions

- modify `write` : `(write obj :base 10 :radix t :stream *any-output*)`
- modify  `write-string` : `(write-string string *standard-output* :start 2 :end 4)`
                                     `(write-string string)`
                                     `(write-string string stream)`
                                     `(write-string string stream :end 4)`
- add new `write-line` :  `(write-line string stream :start 2 :end 3)`
                                    `(write-line string)`
                                     `(write-line string stream)`
                                     `(write-line string stream :end 4)`
- add new `fresh-line`:  `(fresh-line &optional stream)
- modify `terpri`: `(terpri &optional stream)`
- add new `replace` : (replace seq1 seq2 &key :start1 :end 1 :start2 :end2)
                                seq1 & seq2 must be of the same type, `string` or `vector`
- pathed `trace` for prevent error `Maximum call stack size exceeded`
               see Issue #402

review.body:
It looks good!

I asked before if `(format *standard-output*` was equivalent to `(format t ..)` and you said yes.  I guess the correct question was, is there a reason why we do `(format *standard-output*`) instead?  it seems longer.

But it works and I'm okay with it. 

- There is a small typo too if you want to fix it.

I can merge it by the end of today, so feel free to make any small adjustments you like!

issue.title: Type checking
issue.body:
I'm trying to perform some computations on the browser-side, which is rather slow sometimes.
I see in the JSCL-generated code a lot of type checking like this:

```
var x2=Math.sqrt(v25);
if (typeof x2!='number') throw 'Not a number!';
```

It seems strange, because Math.sqrt can return numbers only and, anyway, that checks are slowdowns the code.
Is there a way to disable type checking in generated code?

comment.body:
I think the default should be to check the types always.
But we can disable them kind of easily with a declaration without improving the compiler.
Indeed if the user chooses `safety 0`,  then they could add `check-type`.

+(defun %replace-seq-eql (x y)
+  (typecase x
+    (number (and (numberp y) (= x y)))
+    (character (and (characterp y) (char-equal x y)))
+    (string
+     (and (stringp y)
+          (equal x y) ))

+    (t (equal x y))))

- modify  `write-string` : `(write-string string *standard-output* :start 2 :end 4)`
                                     `(write-string string)`
                                     `(write-string string stream)`
                                     `(write-string string stream :end 4)`
- add new `write-line` :  `(write-line string stream :start 2 :end 3)`
                                    `(write-line string)`
                                     `(write-line string stream)`
                                     `(write-line string stream :end 4)`
- add new `fresh-line`:  `(fresh-line &optional stream)
- modify `terpri`: `(terpri &optional stream)`
- add new `replace` : (replace seq1 seq2 &key :start1 :end 1 :start2 :end2)
                                seq1 & seq2 must be of the same type, `string` or `vector`
- pathed `trace` for prevent error `Maximum call stack size exceeded`
               see Issue #402

comment.body:
Why the change from `(format t` to `(format *standard-output`? Shouldn't it be the same?

> If destination is [t](http://www.lispworks.com/documentation/HyperSpec/Body/a_t.htm#t), the output is sent to [standard output](http://www.lispworks.com/documentation/HyperSpec/Body/26_glo_s.htm#standard_output).

T

JSCL

issue.title: Lambda list in function description

Can we have the lambda-list of functions as part of their descriptions.?

comment.body:
Can we expose this under a `function-lambda-list` function (inside the `jscl` package)?

I wonder also if it'd be a good idea to make this pluggable somehow. We could define a `(defvar *collect-lambda-lists* ...)` variable or something.

That way there is no need to pay the price for the extra bundle if desired.  That would allow to change it dynamically too.

Thoughts?

pull_request.title: Ensure unboundFunction is bound to the right symbol
pull_request.body:
That way the error messagae will be correct regardless if we invoke it
like symbol.fvalue() or if we assign it first into a variable, losing
the `this` context.

## Detailed

I started debugging #438, narrow it down to this simple issue:

```
(search "a" "b" :test 'equalp)
; ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

It should be more intuitive than that error. Like the regular `equalp` is not bound.

Looking at the definition, and how it dispatches by sequence type, I tried with other couple of sequences:
https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/sequence.lisp#L353-L383

```
CL-USER> (search '(1) '(2) :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
CL-USER> (search #(1) #(2) :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

still happens.  So it seems that it migth be in the generic util `satisfies-test-p`, and indeed:

```
CL-USER> (in-package :jscl)
#<PACKAGE JSCL>
JSCL> (satisfies-test-p 1 2)
NIL
JSCL> (satisfies-test-p 1 2 :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

The only thing this does is [calling `funcall`](https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/utils.lisp#L123)

So we can simplify it even more to just `funcall`:

```
CL-USER> (funcall 'f)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

At this point this is a primitive compilation defined in the compiler.  I did generate the code for that simple example with

```lisp
(jscl::with-compilation-environment
  (jscl::compile-toplevel '(funcall 'f)))
```

resulting in:

```javascript
var l1=internals.intern('F','CL-USER');
(function(){
  var F=l1;
  return (typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue)(internals.pv);
})();
```

Not a lot happening..  no mention of the `name`.  Except I noticed something.  `symbol.fvalue` is  initialized to `unboundFunction` in order to generate an error if a undefined function is called. Code code in prelude is

https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/prelude.js#L334-L336

This could explain.  If `unboundFunction`'s **this** is only defined if we call it like symb.fvalue.  If we get that value out into another expression and call it.  `this` will be undefined.

We can try that int he JS console:

```javascript
jscl.internals.intern('F').fvalue()
/*
jscl.js:337 Uncaught Error: Function 'F' undefined
    at internals.unboundFunction [as fvalue] (jscl.js:337:9)
    at <anonymous>:1:30
*/
```

that is correct. But if the compiler generates:

```javascript
(true? jscl.internals.intern('F').fvalue: null)()
/*
jscl.js:337 Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
    at internals.unboundFunction (jscl.js:337:39)
    at <anonymous>:1:48
internals.unboundFunction @ jscl.js:337
(anonymous) @ VM984:1
*/
```

Then we can reproduce the problem.

That is kind of what the compiler generates!

```
(typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue)(internals.pv);
```

Possible solutions for this would be:

- Not using `this` in `unboundSymbol`, [bind it](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_objects/Function/bind) it to the symbol when the symbol is `intern`ed
- Changing the generated code to make sure we call the function with the right `this` context associated.

We could generate fo rinstance
```
(typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue).call(F, internals.pv);
```

The `bind` method is more robust probably.

repo.description: A Lisp-to-Javascript compiler bootstrapped from Common Lisp

commits.message:
Ensure unboundFunction is bound to the right symbol

That way the error messagae will be correct regardless if we invoke it
like symbol.fvalue() or if we assign it first into a variable, losing
the `this` context.

Mark unbound .fvalue value to detect it in FBOUNDP

As we're binding the function to the symbol with .bind(), we lose the
identity check for `unboundFunction`.

Instead, mark the function with a special symbol so we can detect the
symbol is unbound.

Improve FBOUNDP error message

By moving the condition to the FBOUNDP wrapper function, we have access
to the proper `ERROR` function.

Merge pull request #439 from jscl-project/fix-funcall-error-message

Ensure unboundFunction is bound to the right symbol

We could generate fo rinstance

comment.body: @vlad-km thanks for the review!

commits.message:
Improve FBOUNDP error message

By moving the condition to the FBOUNDP wrapper function, we have access
to the proper `ERROR` function.

comment.body: I guess `fboundp` is not super important for performance, so I'll do that :-)

This could explain.  If `unboundFunction`'s **this** is only defined if we call it like symb.fvalue.  If we get that value out into another expression and call it.  `this` will be undefined.

We can try that int he JS console:

```javascript
jscl.internals.intern('F').fvalue()
/*
jscl.js:337 Uncaught Error: Function 'F' undefined
    at internals.unboundFunction [as fvalue] (jscl.js:337:9)
    at <anonymous>:1:30
*/
```

that is correct. But if the compiler generates:

```javascript
(true? jscl.internals.intern('F').fvalue: null)()
/*
jscl.js:337 Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
    at internals.unboundFunction (jscl.js:337:39)
    at <anonymous>:1:48
internals.unboundFunction @ jscl.js:337
(anonymous) @ VM984:1
*/
```

Then we can reproduce the problem.

That is kind of what the compiler generates!

```
(typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue)(internals.pv);
```

Possible solutions for this would be:

- Not using `this` in `unboundSymbol`, [bind it](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_objects/Function/bind) it to the symbol when the symbol is `intern`ed
- Changing the generated code to make sure we call the function with the right `this` context associated.

We could generate fo rinstance
```
(typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue).call(F, internals.pv);
```

The `bind` method is more robust probably.

pull_request.body:
That way the error messagae will be correct regardless if we invoke it
like symbol.fvalue() or if we assign it first into a variable, losing
the `this` context.

## Detailed

I started debugging #438, narrow it down to this simple issue:

```
(search "a" "b" :test 'equalp)
; ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

It should be more intuitive than that error. Like the regular `equalp` is not bound.

Looking at the definition, and how it dispatches by sequence type, I tried with other couple of sequences:
https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/sequence.lisp#L353-L383

```
CL-USER> (search '(1) '(2) :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
CL-USER> (search #(1) #(2) :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

still happens.  So it seems that it migth be in the generic util `satisfies-test-p`, and indeed:

```
CL-USER> (in-package :jscl)
#<PACKAGE JSCL>
JSCL> (satisfies-test-p 1 2)
NIL
JSCL> (satisfies-test-p 1 2 :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

The only thing this does is [calling `funcall`](https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/utils.lisp#L123)

So we can simplify it even more to just `funcall`:

```
CL-USER> (funcall 'f)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

At this point this is a primitive compilation defined in the compiler.  I did generate the code for that simple example with

```lisp
(jscl::with-compilation-environment
  (jscl::compile-toplevel '(funcall 'f)))
```

resulting in:

```javascript
var l1=internals.intern('F','CL-USER');
(function(){
  var F=l1;
  return (typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue)(internals.pv);
})();
```

Not a lot happening..  no mention of the `name`.  Except I noticed something.  `symbol.fvalue` is  initialized to `unboundFunction` in order to generate an error if a undefined function is called. Code code in prelude is

https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/prelude.js#L334-L336

This could explain.  If `unboundFunction`'s **this** is only defined if we call it like symb.fvalue.  If we get that value out into another expression and call it.  `this` will be undefined.

We can try that int he JS console:

```javascript
jscl.internals.intern('F').fvalue()
/*
jscl.js:337 Uncaught Error: Function 'F' undefined
    at internals.unboundFunction [as fvalue] (jscl.js:337:9)
    at <anonymous>:1:30
*/
```

that is correct. But if the compiler generates:

```javascript
(true? jscl.internals.intern('F').fvalue: null)()
/*
jscl.js:337 Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
    at internals.unboundFunction (jscl.js:337:39)
    at <anonymous>:1:48
internals.unboundFunction @ jscl.js:337
(anonymous) @ VM984:1
*/
```

Then we can reproduce the problem.

That is kind of what the compiler generates!

```
(typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue)(internals.pv);
```

Possible solutions for this would be:

- Not using `this` in `unboundSymbol`, [bind it](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_objects/Function/bind) it to the symbol when the symbol is `intern`ed
- Changing the generated code to make sure we call the function with the right `this` context associated.

We could generate fo rinstance
```
(typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue).call(F, internals.pv);
```

The `bind` method is more robust probably.

commits.message: Show correct package in nodejs prompt

Add Deno support

This adds support for Deno. https://deno.land/

Closes #407

Add return value to `defpackage`

According to the HyperSpec, `defpackage` should return the declared package.

>    defpackage creates a package as specified and returns the package.

Also add a test that checks for this behavior.

http://clhs.lisp.se/Body/m_defpkg.htm#defpackage

Readable printing of structs

This change prints structs created with `defstruct` in a readble format.

Instead of printing `#<instance STRUCTURE-CLASS FOO ...>`, we print
`#S(FOO ...)`. This allows a parser to reinstantiate this structure from
a string.

Sharpsign S: http://clhs.lisp.se/Body/02_dhm.htm
Printing Structures: http://clhs.lisp.se/Body/22_acl.htm

Refactor symbol-name calculation for setf-functions

The symbol name for `(defun (setf ...) ...)` like functions is now done
in `%defun-setf-symbol`.

Merge pull request #418 from nagy/fdefinition-setf

FDEFINITION should support setf declarations

Merge pull request #421 from vlad-km/02022022

macro ASSERT #395
added call DEFMETHOD without prior DEFGENERIC

Merge pull request #422 from vlad-km/08022022

Macro DEFMETHOD #416

Merge pull request #432 from Uthar/master

add CONCATENATE

Treat numbers as strings when accessing properties

With this change, numbers are now treated as strings when setting
properties of javascript objects. This aligns with how object properties
are accessed in javascript already:

```sh
$ node
Welcome to Node.js v18.7.0.
Type ".help" for more information.
> var o = {}
undefined
> o[111] = 222
222
> o["111"]
222
>
```

Before this, the following error would be thrown.

```
CL-USER> (jscl::oset 222 (jscl::new) 111)
ERROR: activechars.join is not a function
CL-USER>
```

comment.body:
Good catch!  You are right.  We check for `x.fvalue === unboundFunction` to know if a symbol is bound or not, and that doesn't work anymore with `.bind`.

We need a way to check for it now.

issue.title: Debugging ?
issue.body:
Hi,

is there a way for me to debug things when something goes wrong ? Like, get a backtrace or something.

I'm trying this at JSCL repl:

```lisp
CL-USER> (defun ilt-apropos (string) 
...   (let (found) 
...     (dolist (package (list-all-packages)) 
...       (do-external-symbols (sym package) 
... 	(when (search string (symbol-name sym) :test 'equalp) 
... 	  (push sym found)))) 
...     found))
ILT-APROPOS
```

But I get:

```lisp
CL-USER> (ilt-apropos "list") 
... 
ERROR: this is undefined
```

It works in SBCL for example, so it is not that my function is buggy.

Thanks!

issue.title: Relicensing to MIT?
issue.body:
**We are considering changing the license of JSCL from GPL3 to MIT.**

To do so, we need contributors of significant parts of JSCL to agree.

If you are in this list, **please comment in this thread telling us if you agree or not**.

I apology for the ping if you are not interested.

Some contributions are small enough that we won't need permission. Below follows the contributions by author according to
[git-quick-stats](https://github.com/arzzen/git-quick-stats).

Even if you aren't a contributor, you can react with +1 or -1 to this issue to express your thoughts on the change.

forkee.name: cornerstone3D-beta
forkee.description: Cornerstone is a set of JavaScript libraries that can be used to build web-based medical imaging applications. It provides a framework to build radiology applications such as the OHIF Viewer.

issue.title: Relicensing to MIT?
issue.body:
**We are considering changing the license of JSCL from GPL3 to MIT.**

To do so, we need contributors of significant parts of JSCL to agree.

If you are in this list, **please comment in this thread telling us if you agree or not**.

I apology for the ping if you are not interested.

Some contributions are small enough that we won't need permission. Below follows the contributions by author according to
[git-quick-stats](https://github.com/arzzen/git-quick-stats).

Even if you aren't a contributor, you can react with +1 or -1 to this issue to express your thoughts on the change.

## Approve
- [x] Andrea Griffini <agriff@tin.it> @6502 
- [x] Robert Smith <quad@symbo1ics.com> @stylewarning 
- [x] Nikodemus Siivola <nikodemus@random-state.net> @nikodemus

comment.body:
@kengruven You are right in that many times there is no a good (logical) reason for such a change. In many cases, they could do exactly the same with GPL. I don't think that is true for JSCL.  But regardless,  I think that is the wrong approach, because nobody is going to convince anyone else about it.

That is why, instead, I emphasized the argument of "some people are more comfortable with it", it seems silly, but that is sometimes perfectly valid! Sometimes we accept changes that are not ideal for us, just to keep people on board.  We do that with pull requests all the time.

The fact is, some people want that change, whatever theirs (possibly wrong) reasons. So is this change unacceptable and worth blocking, or not really such a big deal?

(I realize the question doesn't sound 100% honest. We could ask the reverse, "why is changing GPL->MIT a big deal? why can't they concede?" Well, they won't concede and I don't think it's a battle worth picking)

review.body:
Nice!  That is a nice improvement.

I think I'd like a small change.

I would like to keep a function that is useful to make requests programatically. Before this change, that function was `graphql--query` and `graphql-post-request`. But now the callback in them means you can't build your own functions on top of it.

I'd propose to add two arguments `sync` and `success` callback arguments to them, and only pass the callback from the interactive `graphql-send-query` function.

Then it is probably a good idea to still keep the `:parser 'json-read`.  But feel free to add still another argument to it and pass `buffer-string` from the query if you want.

Hm,  with those changes, I also feel comfortable of making the interactive function always async and not even introduce a custom.

Thoughts?

pull_request.title: Implement support for async requests
pull_request.body:
I did this mostly because `request.el` is bugged for me on synchronous requests. But I think it's a nice addition anyway (it has bothered me many times before that emacs would hang while the request is running, specially when I setup some debugging breakpoints in the server).

Hope you find this useful.

Thanks a lot for this package.

comment.body:
> I'm totally OK with the change to MIT, but I'd love to know if there was a motivating factor, and whether the developers think it will encourage their own further development. 🙂

Good point. We're hearing lot of people 'not opposing' to it, but not if it'll make it easier for them to use. I'd love to hear that from others too!

This is the (latest) thread where the topic came up:
https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/discussions/441#discussioncomment-3580135

**My opinion**: I like copyleft but I think it doesn't fit a Lisp implementation well.  I'd like people to feel comfortable that they can use it without making their work GPL too.  By nature in Lisp, it's hard to state what is a 'improvement' to jscl vs just using it.  (what if you do `(defun cl:mapcar ...)` in your application?  I think the simplicity of MIT wins and it would solve that.

issue.title: Relicensing to MIT?
issue.body:
**We are considering changing the license of JSCL from GPL3 to MIT.**

To do so, we need contributors of significant parts of JSCL to agree.

If you are in this list, **please comment in this thread telling us if you agree or not**.

I apology for the ping if you are not interested.

Some contributions are small enough that we won't need permission. Below follows the contributions by author according to
[git-quick-stats](https://github.com/arzzen/git-quick-stats).

Even if you aren't a contributor, you can react with +1 or -1 to this issue to express your thoughts on the change.

comment.body:
Just want to leave my (lack of) opinion here as well.  I don't mind GPLv3 vs MIT, I agree with @nagy's argument, but I think it's unlikely to happen. And even if I don't think there is a reason to reject it because it's GPLv3 (you can make your app on it,  just contribute changes to jscl itself), it seems many people feel that way.

However I have been asked a few timesthis already, so it that makes more people likely to use and contribute to the project, I welcome the change.

issue.title: Relicensing to MIT?
issue.body:
**We are considering changing the license of JSCL from GPL3 to MIT.**

To do so, we need contributors of significant parts of JSCL to agree.

If you are in this list, **please comment in this thread telling us if you agree or not**.

Some contributions are small enough that we won't need permission.
Below follows the contributions by author according to
[git-quick-stats](https://github.com/arzzen/git-quick-stats).

pull_request.title: Some update array features
pull_request.body:
1. (make-array) - now can use :fill-pointer as `t` | `(integer 0 32767)`
2. add function ```(vector-pop vector)```
3. add function ```(vector-push new-val vector)``` 

for details, look at:
1. http://clhs.lisp.se/Body/f_vec_ps.htm
2. http://clhs.lisp.se/Body/f_mk_ar.htm
3. http://clhs.lisp.se/Body/f_vec_po.htm

test cases, also attached

pull_request.title: Some features and pathes
pull_request.body:
- add `*print-base*`, `*print-radix*` variables
- modify `write` : `(write obj :base 10 :radix t :stream *any-output*)`
- modify  `write-string` : `(write-string string *standard-output* :start 2 :end 4)`
                                     `(write-string string)`
                                     `(write-string string stream)`
                                     `(write-string string stream :end 4)`
- add new `write-line` :  `(write-line string stream :start 2 :end 3)`
                                    `(write-line string)`
                                     `(write-line string stream)`
                                     `(write-line string stream :end 4)`
- add new `fresh-line`:  `(fresh-line &optional stream)
- modify `terpri`: `(terpri &optional stream)`
- add new `replace` : (replace seq1 seq2 &key :start1 :end 1 :start2 :end2)
                                seq1 & seq2 must be of the same type, `string` or `vector`
- pathed `trace` for prevent error `Maximum call stack size exceeded`
               see Issue #402

comment.body: Looks great, thank you!

review.body:
It looks good!

I asked before if `(format *standard-output*` was equivalent to `(format t ..)` and you said yes.  I guess the correct question was, is there a reason why we do `(format *standard-output*`) instead?  it seems longer.

But it works and I'm okay with it. 

- There is a small typo too if you want to fix it.

I can merge it by the end of today, so feel free to make any small adjustments you like!

issue.title: Type checking
issue.body:
I'm trying to perform some computations on the browser-side, which is rather slow sometimes.
I see in the JSCL-generated code a lot of type checking like this:

```
var x2=Math.sqrt(v25);
if (typeof x2!='number') throw 'Not a number!';
```

It seems strange, because Math.sqrt can return numbers only and, anyway, that checks are slowdowns the code.
Is there a way to disable type checking in generated code?

comment.body:
I think the default should be to check the types always.
But we can disable them kind of easily with a declaration without improving the compiler.
Indeed if the user chooses `safety 0`,  then they could add `check-type`.

+(defun %replace-seq-eql (x y)

Why the change from `(format t` to `(format *standard-output`? Shouldn't it be the same?

> If destination is [t](http://www.lispworks.com/documentation/HyperSpec/Body/a_t.htm#t), the output is sent to [standard output](http://www.lispworks.com/documentation/HyperSpec/Body/26_glo_s.htm#standard_output).

issue.title: SIMPLE-VECTOR
issue.body:
ABCL:
```
CL-USER(1): (typep #(1 2) '(simple-vector 2))
T
```

JSCL
```
CL-USER>  (typep #(1 2) '(simple-vector 2))
ERROR: Unknown type-specifier (SIMPLE-VECTOR 2).
```

comment.body: Sure but then `(typep #(1 2) '(simple-vector 2))` should return `T` instead of throwing the error?

#<FUNCTION !FORMAT>
Class: #<builtin-in-class FUNCTION>
Name:!FORMAT
Lambda list:(DESTINATION FMT &REST ARGS)
```

comment.body:
Can we expose this under a `function-lambda-list` function (inside the `jscl` package)?

I wonder also if it'd be a good idea to make this pluggable somehow. We could define a `(defvar *collect-lambda-lists* ...)` variable or something.

That way there is no need to pay the price for the extra bundle if desired.  That would allow to change it dynamically too.

Thoughts?

pull_request.title: Ensure unboundFunction is bound to the right symbol
pull_request.body:
That way the error messagae will be correct regardless if we invoke it
like symbol.fvalue() or if we assign it first into a variable, losing
the `this` context.

## Detailed

I started debugging #438, narrow it down to this simple issue:

```
(search "a" "b" :test 'equalp)
; ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

It should be more intuitive than that error. Like the regular `equalp` is not bound.

Looking at the definition, and how it dispatches by sequence type, I tried with other couple of sequences:
https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/sequence.lisp#L353-L383

```
CL-USER> (search '(1) '(2) :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
CL-USER> (search #(1) #(2) :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

still happens.  So it seems that it migth be in the generic util `satisfies-test-p`, and indeed:

```
CL-USER> (in-package :jscl)
#<PACKAGE JSCL>
JSCL> (satisfies-test-p 1 2)
NIL
JSCL> (satisfies-test-p 1 2 :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

The only thing this does is [calling `funcall`](https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/utils.lisp#L123)

So we can simplify it even more to just `funcall`:

```
CL-USER> (funcall 'f)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

At this point this is a primitive compilation defined in the compiler.  I did generate the code for that simple example with

```lisp
(jscl::with-compilation-environment
  (jscl::compile-toplevel '(funcall 'f)))
```

resulting in:

```javascript
var l1=internals.intern('F','CL-USER');
(function(){
  var F=l1;
  return (typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue)(internals.pv);
})();
```

Not a lot happening..  no mention of the `name`.  Except I noticed something.  `symbol.fvalue` is  initialized to `unboundFunction` in order to generate an error if a undefined function is called. Code code in prelude is

https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/prelude.js#L334-L336

This could explain.  If `unboundFunction`'s **this** is only defined if we call it like symb.fvalue.  If we get that value out into another expression and call it.  `this` will be undefined.

We can try that int he JS console:

```javascript
jscl.internals.intern('F').fvalue()
/*
jscl.js:337 Uncaught Error: Function 'F' undefined
    at internals.unboundFunction [as fvalue] (jscl.js:337:9)
    at <anonymous>:1:30
*/
```

that is correct. But if the compiler generates:

```javascript
(true? jscl.internals.intern('F').fvalue: null)()
/*
jscl.js:337 Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
    at internals.unboundFunction (jscl.js:337:39)
    at <anonymous>:1:48
internals.unboundFunction @ jscl.js:337
(anonymous) @ VM984:1
*/
```

Then we can reproduce the problem.

That is kind of what the compiler generates!

```
(typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue)(internals.pv);
```

Possible solutions for this would be:

- Not using `this` in `unboundSymbol`, [bind it](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_objects/Function/bind) it to the symbol when the symbol is `intern`ed
- Changing the generated code to make sure we call the function with the right `this` context associated.

We could generate fo rinstance
```
(typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue).call(F, internals.pv);
```

The `bind` method is more robust probably.

repo.description: A Lisp-to-Javascript compiler bootstrapped from Common Lisp

repo.name: jscl
repo.description: A Lisp-to-Javascript compiler bootstrapped from Common Lisp

commits.message:
Ensure unboundFunction is bound to the right symbol

That way the error messagae will be correct regardless if we invoke it
like symbol.fvalue() or if we assign it first into a variable, losing
the `this` context.

Mark unbound .fvalue value to detect it in FBOUNDP

As we're binding the function to the symbol with .bind(), we lose the
identity check for `unboundFunction`.

Instead, mark the function with a special symbol so we can detect the
symbol is unbound.

Improve FBOUNDP error message

By moving the condition to the FBOUNDP wrapper function, we have access
to the proper `ERROR` function.

Merge pull request #439 from jscl-project/fix-funcall-error-message

Ensure unboundFunction is bound to the right symbol

```lisp

  (jscl::compile-toplevel '(funcall 'f)))
```

resulting in:

(function(){

  return (typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue)(internals.pv);
})();
```

https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/prelude.js#L334-L336

By moving the condition to the FBOUNDP wrapper function, we have access

comment.body: I guess `fboundp` is not super important for performance, so I'll do that :-)

commits.message: Show correct package in nodejs prompt

Add Deno support

This adds support for Deno. https://deno.land/

Closes #407

Add return value to `defpackage`

According to the HyperSpec, `defpackage` should return the declared package.

>    defpackage creates a package as specified and returns the package.

Also add a test that checks for this behavior.

http://clhs.lisp.se/Body/m_defpkg.htm#defpackage

Readable printing of structs

This change prints structs created with `defstruct` in a readble format.

Instead of printing `#<instance STRUCTURE-CLASS FOO ...>`, we print
`#S(FOO ...)`. This allows a parser to reinstantiate this structure from
a string.

Sharpsign S: http://clhs.lisp.se/Body/02_dhm.htm
Printing Structures: http://clhs.lisp.se/Body/22_acl.htm

Refactor symbol-name calculation for setf-functions

The symbol name for `(defun (setf ...) ...)` like functions is now done
in `%defun-setf-symbol`.

Merge pull request #418 from nagy/fdefinition-setf

FDEFINITION should support setf declarations

Merge pull request #421 from vlad-km/02022022

macro ASSERT #395
added call DEFMETHOD without prior DEFGENERIC

Merge pull request #422 from vlad-km/08022022

Macro DEFMETHOD #416

Merge pull request #432 from Uthar/master

add CONCATENATE

Treat numbers as strings when accessing properties

With this change, numbers are now treated as strings when setting
properties of javascript objects. This aligns with how object properties
are accessed in javascript already:

```sh
$ node
Welcome to Node.js v18.7.0.
Type ".help" for more information.
> var o = {}
undefined
> o[111] = 222
222
> o["111"]
222
>
```

Before this, the following error would be thrown.

```
CL-USER> (jscl::oset 222 (jscl::new) 111)
ERROR: activechars.join is not a function
CL-USER>
```

issue.title: Ensure unboundFunction is bound to the right symbol
issue.body:
That way the error messagae will be correct regardless if we invoke it
like symbol.fvalue() or if we assign it first into a variable, losing
the `this` context.

## Detailed

I started debugging #438, narrow it down to this simple issue:

```
(search "a" "b" :test 'equalp)
; ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

It should be more intuitive than that error. Like the regular `equalp` is not bound.

Looking at the definition, and how it dispatches by sequence type, I tried with other couple of sequences:
https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/sequence.lisp#L353-L383

```
CL-USER> (search '(1) '(2) :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
CL-USER> (search #(1) #(2) :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

still happens.  So it seems that it migth be in the generic util `satisfies-test-p`, and indeed:

```
CL-USER> (in-package :jscl)
#<PACKAGE JSCL>
JSCL> (satisfies-test-p 1 2)
NIL
JSCL> (satisfies-test-p 1 2 :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

The only thing this does is [calling `funcall`](https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/utils.lisp#L123)

So we can simplify it even more to just `funcall`:

```
CL-USER> (funcall 'f)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

At this point this is a primitive compilation defined in the compiler.  I did generate the code for that simple example with

```lisp
(jscl::with-compilation-environment
  (jscl::compile-toplevel '(funcall 'f)))
```

resulting in:

```javascript
var l1=internals.intern('F','CL-USER');
(function(){
  var F=l1;
  return (typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue)(internals.pv);
})();
```

Not a lot happening..  no mention of the `name`.  Except I noticed something.  `symbol.fvalue` is  initialized to `unboundFunction` in order to generate an error if a undefined function is called. Code code in prelude is

https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/prelude.js#L334-L336

This could explain.  If `unboundFunction`'s **this** is only defined if we call it like symb.fvalue.  If we get that value out into another expression and call it.  `this` will be undefined.

We can try that int he JS console:

```javascript
jscl.internals.intern('F').fvalue()
/*
jscl.js:337 Uncaught Error: Function 'F' undefined
    at internals.unboundFunction [as fvalue] (jscl.js:337:9)
    at <anonymous>:1:30
*/
```

that is correct. But if the compiler generates:

```javascript
(true? jscl.internals.intern('F').fvalue: null)()
/*
jscl.js:337 Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
    at internals.unboundFunction (jscl.js:337:39)
    at <anonymous>:1:48
internals.unboundFunction @ jscl.js:337
(anonymous) @ VM984:1
*/
```

Then we can reproduce the problem.

That is kind of what the compiler generates!

```
(typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue)(internals.pv);
```

Possible solutions for this would be:

- Not using `this` in `unboundSymbol`, [bind it](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_objects/Function/bind) it to the symbol when the symbol is `intern`ed
- Changing the generated code to make sure we call the function with the right `this` context associated.

We could generate fo rinstance
```
(typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue).call(F, internals.pv);
```

The `bind` method is more robust probably.

comment.body:
Good catch!  You are right.  We check for `x.fvalue === unboundFunction` to know if a symbol is bound or not, and that doesn't work anymore with `.bind`.

We need a way to check for it now.

issue.title: Debugging ?
issue.body:
Hi,

is there a way for me to debug things when something goes wrong ? Like, get a backtrace or something.

I'm trying this at JSCL repl:

```lisp
CL-USER> (defun ilt-apropos (string) 
...   (let (found) 
...     (dolist (package (list-all-packages)) 
...       (do-external-symbols (sym package) 
... 	(when (search string (symbol-name sym) :test 'equalp) 
... 	  (push sym found)))) 
...     found))
ILT-APROPOS
```

But I get:

```lisp
CL-USER> (ilt-apropos "list") 
... 
ERROR: this is undefined
```

It works in SBCL for example, so it is not that my function is buggy.

Thanks!

issue.title: Relicensing to MIT?
issue.body:

To do so, we need contributors of significant parts of JSCL to agree.

If you are in this list, **please comment in this thread telling us if you agree or not**.

I apology for the ping if you are not interested.

Some contributions are small enough that we won't need permission. Below follows the contributions by author according to

comment.body:
@kengruven You are right in that many times there is no a good (logical) reason for such a change. In many cases, they could do exactly the same with GPL. I don't think that is true for JSCL.  But regardless,  I think that is the wrong approach, because nobody is going to convince anyone else about it.

That is why, instead, I emphasized the argument of "some people are more comfortable with it", it seems silly, but that is sometimes perfectly valid! Sometimes we accept changes that are not ideal for us, just to keep people on board.  We do that with pull requests all the time.

The fact is, some people want that change, whatever theirs (possibly wrong) reasons. So is this change unacceptable and worth blocking, or not really such a big deal?

(I realize the question doesn't sound 100% honest. We could ask the reverse, "why is changing GPL->MIT a big deal? why can't they concede?" Well, they won't concede and I don't think it's a battle worth picking)

comment.body:
Before we continue with the people missing, I think Ken Harris opposition is already quite significant, as he has contributed quite a lot and important code.

https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/commits/master?author=kengruven

```
         Ken Harris <kengruven@gmail.com>:

review.body:
Nice!  That is a nice improvement.

I think I'd like a small change.

I would like to keep a function that is useful to make requests programatically. Before this change, that function was `graphql--query` and `graphql-post-request`. But now the callback in them means you can't build your own functions on top of it.

I'd propose to add two arguments `sync` and `success` callback arguments to them, and only pass the callback from the interactive `graphql-send-query` function.

Then it is probably a good idea to still keep the `:parser 'json-read`.  But feel free to add still another argument to it and pass `buffer-string` from the query if you want.

Hm,  with those changes, I also feel comfortable of making the interactive function always async and not even introduce a custom.

Thoughts?

pull_request.title: Implement support for async requests
pull_request.body:
I did this mostly because `request.el` is bugged for me on synchronous requests. But I think it's a nice addition anyway (it has bothered me many times before that emacs would hang while the request is running, specially when I setup some debugging breakpoints in the server).

Hope you find this useful.

Thanks a lot for this package.

issue.title: Relicensing to MIT?
issue.body:
**We are considering changing the license of JSCL from GPL3 to MIT.**

To do so, we need contributors of significant parts of JSCL to agree.

If you are in this list, **please comment in this thread telling us if you agree or not**.

I apology for the ping if you are not interested.

Some contributions are small enough that we won't need permission. Below follows the contributions by author according to
[git-quick-stats](https://github.com/arzzen/git-quick-stats).

Even if you aren't a contributor, you can react with +1 or -1 to this issue to express your thoughts on the change.

comment.body:
> I'm totally OK with the change to MIT, but I'd love to know if there was a motivating factor, and whether the developers think it will encourage their own further development. 🙂

Good point. We're hearing lot of people 'not opposing' to it, but not if it'll make it easier for them to use. I'd love to hear that from others too!

This is the (latest) thread where the topic came up:
https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/discussions/441#discussioncomment-3580135

**My opinion**: I like copyleft but I think it doesn't fit a Lisp implementation well.  I'd like people to feel comfortable that they can use it without making their work GPL too.  By nature in Lisp, it's hard to state what is a 'improvement' to jscl vs just using it.  (what if you do `(defun cl:mapcar ...)` in your application?  I think the simplicity of MIT wins and it would solve that.

issue.title: Relicensing to MIT?
issue.body:
**We are considering changing the license of JSCL from GPL3 to MIT.**

To do so, we need contributors of significant parts of JSCL to agree.

If you are in this list, **please comment in this thread telling us if you agree or not**.

I apology for the ping if you are not interested.

Some contributions are small enough that we won't need permission. Below follows the contributions by author according to
[git-quick-stats](https://github.com/arzzen/git-quick-stats).

Even if you aren't a contributor, you can react with +1 or -1 to this issue to express your thoughts on the change.

comment.body:
Just want to leave my (lack of) opinion here as well.  I don't mind GPLv3 vs MIT, I agree with @nagy's argument, but I think it's unlikely to happen. And even if I don't think there is a reason to reject it because it's GPLv3 (you can make your app on it,  just contribute changes to jscl itself), it seems many people feel that way.

However I have been asked a few timesthis already, so it that makes more people likely to use and contribute to the project, I welcome the change.

pull_request.title: Some update array features
pull_request.body:
1. (make-array) - now can use :fill-pointer as `t` | `(integer 0 32767)`
2. add function ```(vector-pop vector)```
3. add function ```(vector-push new-val vector)``` 

for details, look at:
1. http://clhs.lisp.se/Body/f_vec_ps.htm
2. http://clhs.lisp.se/Body/f_mk_ar.htm
3. http://clhs.lisp.se/Body/f_vec_po.htm

test cases, also attached

pull_request.title: Some features and pathes
pull_request.body:
- add `*print-base*`, `*print-radix*` variables
- modify `write` : `(write obj :base 10 :radix t :stream *any-output*)`
- modify  `write-string` : `(write-string string *standard-output* :start 2 :end 4)`
                                     `(write-string string)`
                                     `(write-string string stream)`
                                     `(write-string string stream :end 4)`
- add new `write-line` :  `(write-line string stream :start 2 :end 3)`
                                    `(write-line string)`
                                     `(write-line string stream)`
                                     `(write-line string stream :end 4)`
- add new `fresh-line`:  `(fresh-line &optional stream)
- modify `terpri`: `(terpri &optional stream)`
- add new `replace` : (replace seq1 seq2 &key :start1 :end 1 :start2 :end2)
                                seq1 & seq2 must be of the same type, `string` or `vector`
- pathed `trace` for prevent error `Maximum call stack size exceeded`
               see Issue #402

comment.body: Looks great, thank you!

review.body:
It looks good!

I asked before if `(format *standard-output*` was equivalent to `(format t ..)` and you said yes.  I guess the correct question was, is there a reason why we do `(format *standard-output*`) instead?  it seems longer.

But it works and I'm okay with it. 

- There is a small typo too if you want to fix it.

I can merge it by the end of today, so feel free to make any small adjustments you like!

issue.title: Type checking
issue.body:
I'm trying to perform some computations on the browser-side, which is rather slow sometimes.
I see in the JSCL-generated code a lot of type checking like this:

```
var x2=Math.sqrt(v25);
if (typeof x2!='number') throw 'Not a number!';
```

It seems strange, because Math.sqrt can return numbers only and, anyway, that checks are slowdowns the code.
Is there a way to disable type checking in generated code?

comment.body:
I think the default should be to check the types always.
But we can disable them kind of easily with a declaration without improving the compiler.
Indeed if the user chooses `safety 0`,  then they could add `check-type`.

comment.body:
Can we expose this under a `function-lambda-list` function (inside the `jscl` package)?

I wonder also if it'd be a good idea to make this pluggable somehow. We could define a `(defvar *collect-lambda-lists* ...)` variable or something.

Thoughts?

pull_request.title: Ensure unboundFunction is bound to the right symbol
pull_request.body:
That way the error messagae will be correct regardless if we invoke it
like symbol.fvalue() or if we assign it first into a variable, losing
the `this` context.

## Detailed

I started debugging #438, narrow it down to this simple issue:

```
(search "a" "b" :test 'equalp)
; ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

It should be more intuitive than that error. Like the regular `equalp` is not bound.

Looking at the definition, and how it dispatches by sequence type, I tried with other couple of sequences:
https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/sequence.lisp#L353-L383

```
CL-USER> (search '(1) '(2) :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
CL-USER> (search #(1) #(2) :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

still happens.  So it seems that it migth be in the generic util `satisfies-test-p`, and indeed:

```
CL-USER> (in-package :jscl)
#<PACKAGE JSCL>
JSCL> (satisfies-test-p 1 2)
NIL
JSCL> (satisfies-test-p 1 2 :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

The only thing this does is [calling `funcall`](https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/utils.lisp#L123)

So we can simplify it even more to just `funcall`:

```
CL-USER> (funcall 'f)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

At this point this is a primitive compilation defined in the compiler.  I did generate the code for that simple example with

```lisp
(jscl::with-compilation-environment
  (jscl::compile-toplevel '(funcall 'f)))
```

resulting in:

```javascript
var l1=internals.intern('F','CL-USER');
(function(){
  var F=l1;
  return (typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue)(internals.pv);
})();
```

Not a lot happening..  no mention of the `name`.  Except I noticed something.  `symbol.fvalue` is  initialized to `unboundFunction` in order to generate an error if a undefined function is called. Code code in prelude is

https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/prelude.js#L334-L336

This could explain.  If `unboundFunction`'s **this** is only defined if we call it like symb.fvalue.  If we get that value out into another expression and call it.  `this` will be undefined.

We can try that int he JS console:

```javascript
jscl.internals.intern('F').fvalue()
/*
jscl.js:337 Uncaught Error: Function 'F' undefined
    at internals.unboundFunction [as fvalue] (jscl.js:337:9)
    at <anonymous>:1:30
*/
```

that is correct. But if the compiler generates:

```javascript
(true? jscl.internals.intern('F').fvalue: null)()
/*
jscl.js:337 Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
    at internals.unboundFunction (jscl.js:337:39)
    at <anonymous>:1:48
internals.unboundFunction @ jscl.js:337
(anonymous) @ VM984:1
*/
```

Then we can reproduce the problem.

That is kind of what the compiler generates!

```
(typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue)(internals.pv);
```

Possible solutions for this would be:

- Not using `this` in `unboundSymbol`, [bind it](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_objects/Function/bind) it to the symbol when the symbol is `intern`ed
- Changing the generated code to make sure we call the function with the right `this` context associated.

We could generate fo rinstance
```
(typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue).call(F, internals.pv);
```

The `bind` method is more robust probably.

commits.message:
Ensure unboundFunction is bound to the right symbol

That way the error messagae will be correct regardless if we invoke it
like symbol.fvalue() or if we assign it first into a variable, losing
the `this` context.

Mark unbound .fvalue value to detect it in FBOUNDP

As we're binding the function to the symbol with .bind(), we lose the
identity check for `unboundFunction`.

Instead, mark the function with a special symbol so we can detect the
symbol is unbound.

Improve FBOUNDP error message

By moving the condition to the FBOUNDP wrapper function, we have access
to the proper `ERROR` function.

Merge pull request #439 from jscl-project/fix-funcall-error-message

Ensure unboundFunction is bound to the right symbol

It should be more intuitive than that error. Like the regular `equalp` is not bound.

Looking at the definition, and how it dispatches by sequence type, I tried with other couple of sequences:
https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/sequence.lisp#L353-L383

```
CL-USER> (search '(1) '(2) :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
CL-USER> (search #(1) #(2) :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

still happens.  So it seems that it migth be in the generic util `satisfies-test-p`, and indeed:

```
CL-USER> (in-package :jscl)
#<PACKAGE JSCL>
JSCL> (satisfies-test-p 1 2)
NIL
JSCL> (satisfies-test-p 1 2 :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

The only thing this does is [calling `funcall`](https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/utils.lisp#L123)

So we can simplify it even more to just `funcall`:

```
CL-USER> (funcall 'f)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

At this point this is a primitive compilation defined in the compiler.  I did generate the code for that simple example with

```lisp
(jscl::with-compilation-environment
  (jscl::compile-toplevel '(funcall 'f)))
```

resulting in:

```javascript
var l1=internals.intern('F','CL-USER');
(function(){
  var F=l1;
  return (typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue)(internals.pv);
})();
```

Not a lot happening..  no mention of the `name`.  Except I noticed something.  `symbol.fvalue` is  initialized to `unboundFunction` in order to generate an error if a undefined function is called. Code code in prelude is

https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/prelude.js#L334-L336

This could explain.  If `unboundFunction`'s **this** is only defined if we call it like symb.fvalue.  If we get that value out into another expression and call it.  `this` will be undefined.

We can try that int he JS console:

```javascript
jscl.internals.intern('F').fvalue()
/*
jscl.js:337 Uncaught Error: Function 'F' undefined
    at internals.unboundFunction [as fvalue] (jscl.js:337:9)
    at <anonymous>:1:30
*/
```

that is correct. But if the compiler generates:

```javascript
(true? jscl.internals.intern('F').fvalue: null)()
/*
jscl.js:337 Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
    at internals.unboundFunction (jscl.js:337:39)
    at <anonymous>:1:48
internals.unboundFunction @ jscl.js:337
(anonymous) @ VM984:1
*/
```

Then we can reproduce the problem.

That is kind of what the compiler generates!

```
(typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue)(internals.pv);
```

Possible solutions for this would be:

- Not using `this` in `unboundSymbol`, [bind it](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_objects/Function/bind) it to the symbol when the symbol is `intern`ed
- Changing the generated code to make sure we call the function with the right `this` context associated.

We could generate fo rinstance
```
(typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue).call(F, internals.pv);
```

The `bind` method is more robust probably.

commits.message: Show correct package in nodejs prompt

Add Deno support

This adds support for Deno. https://deno.land/

Closes #407

Add return value to `defpackage`

According to the HyperSpec, `defpackage` should return the declared package.

>    defpackage creates a package as specified and returns the package.

Also add a test that checks for this behavior.

http://clhs.lisp.se/Body/m_defpkg.htm#defpackage

Readable printing of structs

This change prints structs created with `defstruct` in a readble format.

Instead of printing `#<instance STRUCTURE-CLASS FOO ...>`, we print
`#S(FOO ...)`. This allows a parser to reinstantiate this structure from
a string.

Sharpsign S: http://clhs.lisp.se/Body/02_dhm.htm
Printing Structures: http://clhs.lisp.se/Body/22_acl.htm

Refactor symbol-name calculation for setf-functions

The symbol name for `(defun (setf ...) ...)` like functions is now done
in `%defun-setf-symbol`.

Merge pull request #418 from nagy/fdefinition-setf

FDEFINITION should support setf declarations

Merge pull request #421 from vlad-km/02022022

macro ASSERT #395
added call DEFMETHOD without prior DEFGENERIC

Merge pull request #422 from vlad-km/08022022

Macro DEFMETHOD #416

Merge pull request #432 from Uthar/master

add CONCATENATE

Treat numbers as strings when accessing properties

With this change, numbers are now treated as strings when setting
properties of javascript objects. This aligns with how object properties
are accessed in javascript already:

```sh
$ node
Welcome to Node.js v18.7.0.
Type ".help" for more information.
> var o = {}
undefined
> o[111] = 222
222
> o["111"]
222
>
```

Before this, the following error would be thrown.

```
CL-USER> (jscl::oset 222 (jscl::new) 111)
ERROR: activechars.join is not a function
CL-USER>
```

```

Possible solutions for this would be:

- Not using `this` in `unboundSymbol`, [bind it](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_objects/Function/bind) it to the symbol when the symbol is `intern`ed
- Changing the generated code to make sure we call the function with the right `this` context associated.

We could generate fo rinstance
```
(typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue).call(F, internals.pv);
```

The `bind` method is more robust probably.

comment.body:
Good catch!  You are right.  We check for `x.fvalue === unboundFunction` to know if a symbol is bound or not, and that doesn't work anymore with `.bind`.

We need a way to check for it now.

But I get:

Thanks!

pull_request.title: Ensure unboundFunction is bound to the right symbol
pull_request.body:
That way the error messagae will be correct regardless if we invoke it
like symbol.fvalue() or if we assign it first into a variable, losing
the `this` context.

## Detailed

I started debugging #438, narrow it down to this simple issue:

```
(search "a" "b" :test 'equalp)
; ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

It should be more intuitive than that error. Like the regular `equalp` is not bound.

Looking at the definition, and how it dispatches by sequence type, I tried with other couple of sequences:
https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/sequence.lisp#L353-L383

```
CL-USER> (search '(1) '(2) :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
CL-USER> (search #(1) #(2) :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

still happens.  So it seems that it migth be in the generic util `satisfies-test-p`, and indeed:

```
CL-USER> (in-package :jscl)
#<PACKAGE JSCL>
JSCL> (satisfies-test-p 1 2)
NIL
JSCL> (satisfies-test-p 1 2 :test 'equalp)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

The only thing this does is [calling `funcall`](https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/utils.lisp#L123)

So we can simplify it even more to just `funcall`:

```
CL-USER> (funcall 'f)
ERROR: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
```

At this point this is a primitive compilation defined in the compiler.  I did generate the code for that simple example with

```lisp
(jscl::with-compilation-environment
  (jscl::compile-toplevel '(funcall 'f)))
```

resulting in:

```javascript
var l1=internals.intern('F','CL-USER');
(function(){
  var F=l1;
  return (typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue)(internals.pv);
})();
```

Not a lot happening..  no mention of the `name`.  Except I noticed something.  `symbol.fvalue` is  initialized to `unboundFunction` in order to generate an error if a undefined function is called. Code code in prelude is

https://github.com/jscl-project/jscl/blob/29885f79a236f71d38e1fe2ea73c3158a8324291/src/prelude.js#L334-L336

This could explain.  If `unboundFunction`'s **this** is only defined if we call it like symb.fvalue.  If we get that value out into another expression and call it.  `this` will be undefined.

We can try that int he JS console:

```javascript
jscl.internals.intern('F').fvalue()
/*
jscl.js:337 Uncaught Error: Function 'F' undefined
    at internals.unboundFunction [as fvalue] (jscl.js:337:9)
    at <anonymous>:1:30
*/
```

that is correct. But if the compiler generates:

```javascript
(true? jscl.internals.intern('F').fvalue: null)()
/*
jscl.js:337 Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
    at internals.unboundFunction (jscl.js:337:39)
    at <anonymous>:1:48
internals.unboundFunction @ jscl.js:337
(anonymous) @ VM984:1
*/
```

Then we can reproduce the problem.

That is kind of what the compiler generates!

```
(typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue)(internals.pv);
```

Possible solutions for this would be:

- Not using `this` in `unboundSymbol`, [bind it](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_objects/Function/bind) it to the symbol when the symbol is `intern`ed
- Changing the generated code to make sure we call the function with the right `this` context associated.

We could generate fo rinstance
```
(typeof F==='function'?F:F.fvalue).call(F, internals.pv);
```

The `bind` method is more robust probably.

issue.title: Make hash-table support numbers as keys
issue.body:
This allows numbers to be used as hash-table keys, since they are crudely converted to strings.

Closes #424

comment.body: Awesome!  Thanks!

commits.message:
Treat numbers as strings when accessing properties

With this change, numbers are now treated as strings when setting
properties of javascript objects. This aligns with how object properties
are accessed in javascript already:

```sh
$ node
Welcome to Node.js v18.7.0.
Type ".help" for more information.
> var o = {}
undefined
> o[111] = 222
222
> o["111"]
222
>
```

Before this, the following error would be thrown.

```
CL-USER> (jscl::oset 222 (jscl::new) 111)
ERROR: activechars.join is not a function
CL-USER>
```
Add tests to check if numbers can be used in hashmaps

Merge pull request #431 from nagy/numbers-as-hash-keys

Make hash-table support numbers as keys
